ARE 100B: Intermediate Microeconomics

Winter 2019

title: Jim Teal
text: I’m a PhD candidate at the University of Wisconsin–Madison in the Agricultural and Applied Economics Department. I hold a master’s degree in agricultural and resource economics from the University of California–Davis and a bachelor’s degree in economics from the University of Tennessee. Previously I have worked at the Federal Reserve Board of Governors and interned at the Economic Research Service of the U.S. Department of Agriculture. In 2023, I was selected as a Farm Foundation Agricultural Scholar. My research focuses on diversification, agricultural finance, and risk management, which has led to multiple publications in top agricultural research journals.

title: Publications
text:
Publications

Stevens, A.W. & J. Teal. “Predicting Firm Diversification in Agri-Food Value Chains.” Journal of Food Distribution Research. Forthcoming.
Teal, J. & A. W. Stevens (2023). Race and premium misrating in the U.S. Federal Crop Insurance Program. Applied Economic Perspectives and Policy.
Stevens, A. W. & J. Teal (2023). Diversification and resilience of firms in the agrifood supply chain. American Journal of Agricultural Economics.

Teal, J., “Crop Diversification and Farm Resilience: An Entropy-Based Evaluation of Agricultural Lending Performance”
